text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6MooT English
from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…
speaker: Alice

text: And I'm Rob.
Did I see you arriving in a huge red pick-up truck this morning
speaker: Alice

text: Oh yes, it's great, isn't it?
It's very big… and red
speaker: Alice

text: But Rob, aren't you a supporter of the movement to preserve the environment?
Uh, yes.
A gas-guzzling car for an environmentalist, Rob?
speaker: Alice

text: Isn't that a contradiction? Aren't you being hypocrite?
Well, it's very fuel-efficient, Alice.
It's quite eco-friendly, actually.
Oh, that's ridiculous. And you know it.
Hypocrisy is the subject of today's show.
speaker: Alice

text: And maybe we should start by exploring the meaning of hypocrite.
Can you tell me what did the ancient Greek word hypocrite originally mean?
Was it A, actor, B, politician or C, horse?
speaker: Rob

text: Okay, that's easy. I think it's B, politician.
Well, we'll find out whether you got the answer right or not later in the show.
speaker: Rob

text: Now, these days, the meaning has changed and hypocrite means somebody who says one thing and does another.
Like you telling me not to bite my nails because it's a disgusting habit…
speaker: Rob

text: and then I see you doing it later the same day.
Well, sometimes it's hard to be consistent.
I do think nail biting is disgusting, but then when I'm a bit nervous,
I do it without thinking.
Yes, we're often inconsistent in what we say or do though, aren't we?
Yes.
speaker: Rob

text: Inconsistent means changeable.
speaker: Inconsistent

text: There is an explanation for us sometimes saying one thing and behaving in a very different way.
Let's listen to Professor Clancy Martin at the University of Missouri in the US.
He teaches philosophy so he knows a thing or two about the way we think.
So while you might be enormously compassionate in your role as a teacher or a parent,
speaker: INSERT

text: you might find yourself being quite harsh and direct when it comes to your role as a brother or
a sister. So then you see that now wait a second, if I've got all these inconsistencies all over
the place in my character, can I really say that I am a sincere and authentic individual or am I
just kind of blowing with whichever way my relationship wins kind of incline me?
Professor Clancy Martin. So we play different roles in life and these roles may seem contradictory
speaker: Rob

text: but they're just part of being the same person. Sometimes you're a bit harsh and direct with me,
Alice, aren't you? Do you see yourself as my sister? She used to pick on me.
Harsh means stern and unkind. I don't mean to be unkind to you, Rob.
Or maybe I could try and be more compassionate towards you. It means show a bit of sympathy and
concern now and then.
Hmm, offer me good words. At least promise you'll be nice to me. That you'll bring me tea and biscuits.
Oh, well that's what politicians do. They promise they will do what people want and often they don't.
And it's a big problem for them. Let's talk about politicians and hypocrisy.
speaker: Rob

text: They have to express opinions about so many things that it's easy to catch them out being hypocritical.
And then we, the public, get morally indignant about it.
Yes, to catch somebody out means to discover they have made a mistake.
And morally indignant means being angry about something,
according to the principles of right and wrong.
Let's listen to Professor Martin again talking about the difficulties of being a politician.
I think in our contemporary democracy it's become obvious to most of us that the views that we
speaker: INSERT

text: expect from our politicians and the kinds of views that get our politicians elected
are maybe completely incongruous with the way they lead their personal lives and what they
personally believe. And this is how it can become very morally pernicious, very morally dangerous.
Okay, so we elect politicians based on their views. For example, on the environment, on education,
foreign policy, but their public views may be incongruous or not in agreement with their personal
speaker: incongruous

text: views. And the difference between their public and personal views can be pernicious.
It means deadly or destructive.
Hmm, politicians are under scrutiny all the time. Their personal lives, their public statements.
Now with social media, a thoughtless comment goes viral or spreads very quickly via the internet.
speaker: goes viral

text: That's true. And actually, I posted a photo of my red pickup truck earlier.
Oh, has it gone viral, Rob?
No, but there is a negative comment from the local conservationists.
Oh dear. Well, Rob, I think it's time I told you the answer to today's quiz question.
I asked, what did the ancient Greek word hypocrite originally describe? Was it a actor,
be politician or see horse? And I said be politician.
And you were wrong, I'm afraid. Hypocrites was a technical term for a stage actor and was not
considered an appropriate role for a public figure. In Athens, in the fourth century BC,
the great Orator de Mocenese ridiculed a rival politician who had been a successful actor.
Well, we're running out of time, so can we hear the words we learned today?
speaker: Rob

text: They are hypocrite, inconsistent, harsh, compassionate, catch somebody out, morally indignant,
incongruous, pernicious, go viral.
Well, that's the end of today's six minute English. Don't forget to join us again soon.
Bye-bye.
Bye-bye.
Let's go to English from the BBC.
